item.title: Ok, help me learn ints :P
item.dc:creator: @bigh51 bigh51
item.description:
@bigh51 wrote:

An int is short form for an integer, which is basically just a 32-bit number. Vic is right, java.com is your best bet.[quote=“Trigger*, post:3, topic:231551”] if (npcs[NPCID].npcType == #NPCIDHERE#) {
int Player = npcs[NPCID].StartKilling;
client ppl = (client) server.playerHandler.players[Player];
ppl.minigame += 1;
}[/quote]That’s calling a int from a separate class after declaring the second class, that’s different. Also, that teaches him nothing. Java.com is his best bet.

Read full topic

item.title: Ok, help me learn ints :P
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

Well I am not really familiar with things in Java such as ints, and booleans. For now, I am asking if someone would help me understand ints.

If I am correct, an int is a value.

I am going to write some code here, and it is for an npc killcount minigame. I am not going to actually add the code to my server, so there will probably be things wrong in there.

Ok, so lets see…

If I wanted to make a killcount minigame, I would first declare an int so…

public int minigame = 0;

Now, if that is right, I would make it so if you kill something itll add a count to the minigame int so like?..

if (npcs[NPCID].npcType == #NPCIDHERE#) { int Player = npcs[NPCID].StartKilling; client ppl = (client) server.playerHandler.players[Player]; minigame += 1; }

and then to get into a special dungeon or something with 15 kills it would be like…( i know this code is wrong)

case ####: if(minigame >= 15)) { teleporttoX = ####; teleporttoY = ####; sendMessage("you teleport to the arena"); minigame -= 15; } else sendMessage("You need 15 kills to enter!"); }

and thats it?

PLEASE correct me on any mistakes, I believe that this is valuable informaton to me and future coding due to the fact ints can be extremely helpful lol…

Read full topic
